hi today I'd like to continue the discussion of root Locust techniques that we started in the last session as
you recall root Locust is one of the two principal methods that we're going to use to evaluate the stability of
feedback systems the advantage of this technique along with the second technique which we'll introduce later is
that it gives us a way to start with readily identifi identifiable quantities in particular the loop transmission of
the feedback system and by rather straightforward analytic manipulations
determine the closed loop transfer function or at least the important features of the closed loop transfer
function we also find out that in addition to getting a binary answer to the stability problem in other words are
there any poles of the closed loop transfer function in the right half of the S plane we're also able to get a very good
analog measure of relative stability in other words we can find out how close our system is to instability we can tell
once we've determined that our system is stable what the damping ratio of the dominant closed loop pole pair is and in
fact you can determine many other features of the Clos Loop response that we might be interested in if you recall last time we in fact

we started with a system that had two poles associated with the loop transmission and no zeros both of those
